ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Perhaps because I was not able to complete the readings before the course began, I was expecting something different from this course. I thought the material covered would be more geared toward the decision process for project planning and design, but the course focused more on a specific tool used by non-profit groups.

The concepts are good, the skills are important, the format is terrible. 2 weekends is not enough time for the content, and the long days were hard on motivation. Also, the client relationships, though interesting, were probably too much for the tiny course. 1/2 the class was learning about the organization and it's mission, 1/4 was learning software and 1/4 was learning the concepts and processes.

I think it would make more sense to fold the class into another course about similar topics and programs/software that could be used.Two weekends are one way to work on it but it seemed that some groups were really slowed down and waiting for others - something that wouldn't happen if the class was held over a semester and students could take the project home to work on.Also, if it's a weekend course, there should be coffee and food available.
No further comments

This course was weird. There was way too much focus on how to use the software (available for purchase) and not nearly enough focus on how to think about designing and planning a conservation program.
The course does not work well for two long weekends. There is not enough time to work through a concept.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Opportunity to work with an actual client, an aspect that is lacking in the wildlife conservation curriculum here at FES.
The concepts were great and in was interesting to walk through the logic behind conservation planning at TNC and these other NGOs.
working in teams - my team was great (though I am not sure other students felt the same).
Good to know how to use software.
The client-based aspect of the course and learning Miradi were very helpful and were the best parts of the course.
General exposure to adaptive management.
Learning Miradi Adaptive Management Software
Interacting with a clientExposure to a tool used in the field of conservationIntroduction to Framework for planning conservation programs
Walking methodically through identifying the problem& learning how to use the software.
This course is useful in that this is a software used by a lot of large organizations for assessment. It gives you a very particular, super-structured approach to breaking down conservation problems.
Working in a group to think about and talk out a complex conservation issue.
The opportunity to work through the Miradi software with fellow students and input from the instructors.
Conceptual modeling with MIRAD
I liked that it focused on applicable conservation practices.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It was really, really difficult to be in class for 4 eight-hour days, particularly in February when summer funding applications were due. A course with a more diffuse structure might be better.
the time format was unfortunate. More time/more spaced out time and maybe more time on the logic before going directly into the Miradi software would be good.
time management - knowing how long to give students and sticking to the schedule. I felt there was a lot of downtime as my team waiting for the other teams to finish.
Pace was too slow. WOuld be better to have everyone on computers doing exercises with instructor.

Having more information about the clients and their work/project of interest before the first class would have been helpfulThe all-day classes were not optimal for learning. I would have preferred more class sessions over long class sessions over a handful of days to learn and process the information in a better waySpent a lot of time learning about the project/client during our assigned sessions which took away from time used to design the projectSome groups completed assignments before others, and because we presented our results to the entire group, there was often a lot of downtime where groups that finished early were waiting for other groups to complete the workWould have preferred presenting to the instructors once we finished our assignments, rather than the whole class, because after our presentations most of the time was spent with instructors giving us feedback that wasn't useful to people not in the particular group. Perhaps next time the individual groups could do a presentation to the entire class on the last day, rather than every single day. Most students were unfocused for the end of the day presentations so we didn't get much out of them
It would be helpful to get exposure to the entire adaptive management process, even if choosing a single case study that everyone worked on.
Timing, projects design exercises
The duration - additional portions (or its entirety) of the framework should be studied and applied in more detailThe software has room for improvement
I think the pace could have been much faster& the lectures more engaging.

It should be sold as what it is-- as TSM in a particular software--Miradi-- which is marketed pretty hard and used as a tool in solving conservation problems. The software is interesting, but particularly flawed in dealing with complex human problems, and a little dated in its approach. We talked very little about the integration of monitoring and evaluation data into reshaping programs.
The teaching. The women didn't really have a good way of explaining the material. They often forgot to mention things. And really the whole course was focused on how to use their software.
Clearer expectations would help, as well as perhaps trying to cover less content but covering areas more in depth.
Length of course could be extended
I wish we could see our conservation project through more or that they were more real world. I also did not like that the course was taught to one software program (Miradi).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No lab section.
n/a
Again, the all-day class structure made it difficult to absorb information presented during lectures and to apply it to our cases
It was just fine - no improvements needed.
Directly correlated, classes introduced tools that were used with client(s) during break out sessions

The breakouts to work on material were useful/ interesting, but the lectures themselves were only somewhat useful. They gave an overview to the material, but then the only way to really approach it was by doing it.
Effective relationship

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I found this course moderately valuable for my program. I was frustrated that the assumptions of the Miradi tool were not made explicit and could not be changed. However, knowing that this tool is widely used by non-profit groups I am glad that I will be able to confidently use Miradi in my career and will use that to my advantage when applying for jobs.

It's needed material. I want to work for either an NGO or the US government making decisions about how to manage land. This is important practical information that isn't found elsewhere in the school's offerings.
I am not sure it fits in. It sounded interesting but I am not sure it will translate into my career path.

While the course structure wasn't ideal, the software and skills learned will be helpful to me as i'm interested in conservation work. There are very few courses at FES that are related to conservation science and planning, so I am glad this course was offered and I hope the school will continue adding conservation classes to the curriculum.
See below.
Framework can be applied to my post career plans either as an individual and part of a firm.

I made the mistake of thinking This class would be a good even though I am not studying conservation. I thought it would be a good one credit course, but I would say only take this class if you are studying conservation.
It might be useful on a resume as a software I am reasonably competent in.

I study conservation so it should have fit really well, if it had been done right. The teachers need to do a lot of work in how they present the information. The goal should not be learning how to use the software but learning how to think about and plan a conservation program.
Enable me contribute effectively in the running of my affiliate/co-found NGO
My interests have since evolved; initially I was focused on conservation so it was a good course. Now I am more interested in advocacy and campaigning.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about project planning and adaptive management.
I care about conservation and I want to design and implement conservation projects professionally.
It sounded interesting and I am interested in conservation.
Skills for job
Interested in conservation and designing conservation projects, especially in relation to wildlife and land use planning
I took this course to compliment my research in landscape-scale research and my possible future work in land conservation, protection, or management.
Because It was attractive for a person like me with interest in wild life conservation and project design.
To learn about a real life tool used for conservation programs, gain perspective the operational side of such programs

I thought it was going to talk philosophically and practically about assessment and adaptive management. I liked the client-based aspect of it, but some of the clients were definitely less interesting than others. And the course was not at all what I had hoped it would be.
To learn skills to design and plan better conservation programs.
I was recommended by a recent alumni in the field to take the course.
To get acquainted with the unified tool for managing conservation projects contributed by major notable conservation organization.
I think it would be applicable tools for conservation.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No, as discussed above I thought the course was more on the theory of project design. However, once I adjusted my expectations I was pleased with the course.

I didn't know what to expect but I guess I'm a little underwhelmed for the reasons discussed previously (format, timing, amount of time spent grappling with the software versus learning the actual concepts etc)
not really. I felt like it was too brief and quick of an overview to really be able to use it in the future (i.e., I'll have to reteach myself how to do it)
Yes
Sort of, though I was expecting to get greater exposure to the entire AM process.
Not much
Partially, primarily because the entire framework was not covered in details. The framework may also be limiting in the way it encourages the user to think about the problem.
Nope. Though if I was a professional in the field it probably would have been more useful.
Once I modified my expectations, more so.
No. I learned how to use their software.
Yes
No, it did not introduce too many concepts I was not already familiar with.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to bounce ideas off each other and be able to lean on one another during the process. I think working in groups was instrumental to the course.
it was fine.
The groups were preassigned. My group was great - I don't think that was true for other teams.
Worked with a bunch of first-years who were unprofessional, inattentive, and rude. One individual just decided to leave on the second day because he was bored.

Advantages: learned from different people as everyone had different experiences and diverse perspectivesDisadvantages: some people were late showing up to class and our group work suffered as a result; some people were more familiar with conservation planning than others
The work group was an integral part of the course. Disadvantages = slow to make progress; advantages = excellent realization of real-world decision making.
Learning from each other's experience.
Leveraging on and realizing the strengths and weaknesses of my peers and myself
I got to hear a lot of different perspectives. Discussing and coming up with solutions together was helpful.
Group work was generally a positive experience, but the time allotted was almost too much.
Thinking about a complex conservation issue with many minds wrapped around it was great at pointing out potential problems.

There was a lot of disagreement on model inputs within our group members, which is a great facet of any problem solving effort, but really hindered things when we were trying to achieve a certain output in an allotted amount of time.
The advantage is the diverse knowledge of group members facilitated completion of the projet.Not all group members were committed to group's goal.
We got to brainstorm conservation strategies.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I have no idea what this course will look like in the future but it was interesting
Make sure that you want to learn about the software.
Encourage your group to read up about the client and the project beforehand so you can immediately start working on the project
Know that this course only covers the first few steps of adaptive management. If you want full exposure, petition for a semester-long course.
Good introduction, practical skill, a good time to take it might be second year before taking on a job, or first year before a relevant internship

Introduces you to Miradi which is a software used by many enviro NGOs to create projects. I personally felt that the Miradi system wasn't great, especially if your projects have a lot to do with people and less to do with strict biodiversity conservation.
Only take it if you are interested in learning the software and their method. Not! a good general, overview course.
Don't expect to be fed lunch. Also, realize that this is a technical, specific skill, not an approach, or learning how to do this sort of work.
Learn the software first and then use the time to think through a conservation issue as a group.
Reading course materials ahead of time helps better understanding of lecture.
I'm not sure how useful it is.
